ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-Reflection 1 – 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 1.	What legislation covers the safety of people in the workplace?
questions.hint: Include health + safety + 2015 (or HSWA + 2015).

questions.text: 2.	What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.hint: A hazard is something that can cause harm or injury.

questions.text:
3.	List 2 methods used to identify hazards in the workplace.
1.
questions.hint: Example methods: visual inspection / hazard register / checklist / toolbox talk.
Give a different method to Q3(1).

questions.text: 4.	Once a hazard has been identified, what are the employer’s responsibilities?
questions.hint: Think: eliminate/minimise, communicate, controls, training, PPE.

questions.text:
5.	List 3 health and safety responsibilities of any worker/student.
1.
questions.hint: Example: take reasonable care / follow instructions / wear PPE / report hazards.
Give a different responsibility to Q5(1).
Give a different responsibility to Q5(1) and Q5(2).

questions.text:
6.	Before you enter a workplace your employer is obliged to provide you with specific safety information. List 4 types of information that would ensure they meet this requirement.
1.
questions.hint: Examples: hazards, risk level, controls, emergency procedures, PPE location.
Give a different type of information to Q6(1).
Give a different type of information to Q6(1–2).
Give a different type of information to Q6(1–3).

questions.text: 7.	Where do you get information on the toxicity of the materials that you are working with?
questions.hint: SDS/MSDS or product label/packaging.

The job will only take 10 minutes to complete. Describe the hazard, describe the potential harm and level of risk and describe the actions required to manage this.

ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-Reflection 2 – 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 1.	You are required to unload 15 x 40kg bags of cement off the back of a truck. The storage area is 75 metres away across a drive littered with construction waste. Describe the safest and most efficient means to get the cement into the storage area.
questions.hint: Think: clear pathway, mechanical aids, team lift, reduce carrying.

questions.text: 2.	Describe the correct lifting techniques for a heavy load, such as a bag of cement.
questions.hint: Bend knees, straight back, close to body, no twisting.

questions.text: 3.	Describe the correct technique for carrying a sheet of plywood.
questions.hint: Two people, on edge, communicate, clear visibility.

questions.text: 4.	Identify a risk associated with storing heavy items on shelves.
questions.hint: Falling items or shelf collapse.

questions.text:

questions.text: 6.	Describe the potential consequences of using a water type extinguisher on an electrical fire.

questions.text: 7.	What does the sign to the right represent and when would this area be used?
questions.hint: Assembly/muster point used during evacuation emergencies.

ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-Reflection 3 – 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 1.	Your first job involves working on a roof. You feel uncomfortable at heights. What should you do?
questions.hint: Tell supervisor, request training/supervision, use fall protection.

questions.text: 2.	What is the recommended angle ratio for a ladder when it is set up?
questions.hint: 4:1 (1 out for every 4 up) or approx 75 degrees.

questions.text: 3.	Why are power lines an extreme hazard when you are carrying or using an aluminium ladder?
questions.hint: Aluminium conducts electricity – electrocution risk.

questions.text: 4.	What is the minimum distance the top of a ladder should extend above a working platform?
questions.hint: 1 metre.

questions.text: 5.	Identify the possible consequences of directing compressed air at another person.
questions.hint: Eye injury, debris, skin penetration, air embolism/bloodstream risk.

questions.text:
6.	Identify 3 sources of information that you can use to identify the hazards and precautions associated with a specific product.

1.
questions.hint: Examples: SDS, hazard register, label, instructions, RAMS.

Give a different source to Q6(1–2).

ASSESSMENTS.title: Knowledge Assessment - 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 2.	What is the main purpose of the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015 (‘the Act’)?
questions.hint: Protect workers and others; ensure health & safety; reasonably practicable; go home safe.

questions.text: 3.	What are your responsibilities as a “worker” under the Act?
questions.hint: Reasonable care, follow instructions, PPE, report hazards, protect others.

questions.text: 4.	What is a person conducting a business or undertaking’s (PCBUs) main responsibility under the Act?
questions.hint: Ensure health and safety so far as reasonably practicable; workers and others affected.

questions.text: Electrical
questions.hint: Harm: electric shock/electrocution. Control: check tools, tag out, RCD.

questions.text: Chemical
questions.hint: Harm: burns/poisoning. Control: SDS, PPE, ventilation.

questions.text: Fire
questions.hint: Harm: burns/smoke inhalation. Control: extinguishers, evacuation, keep exits clear.

questions.text: Fumes
questions.hint: Harm: breathing/lung irritation. Control: ventilation, mask/respirator.

questions.text: Gas
questions.hint: Harm: explosion/asphyxiation. Control: isolate, ventilate, secure cylinders.

questions.text: Compressed air
questions.hint: Harm: eye injury/embolism. Control: PPE, never aim at people.

questions.text: Noise
questions.hint: Harm: hearing loss/tinnitus. Control: earmuffs/plugs.

questions.text: Material
questions.hint: Harm: cuts/splinters/crush. Control: gloves, safe handling, correct storage.

questions.text: Falling
questions.hint: Harm: falls/injury. Control: keep walkways clear, barriers, ladder safety.

questions.text: Lifting
questions.hint: Harm: back strain. Control: bend knees, team lift, trolley.

questions.text: 6.	Identify the meanings of the following signs:
questions.hint: Forklifts, keep aisles clear, keep hands clear/guards, fire action chart.

questions.text: a) Fire
questions.hint: Alarm, 111, evacuate, assembly point.

questions.text: b) Earthquake
questions.hint: Drop cover hold, then assemble and account for people.

questions.text: c) Accident:
questions.hint: First aid, report, call ambulance/111 if serious.

questions.text: d) Chemical spill:
questions.hint: Tell supervisor, isolate/evacuate if needed, SDS/PPE, clean only if safe.
